docs.title: Setting up a dev container for Rust
Prerequisites
docs.text:
• VS Code with Dev Containers extension
  • Docker installed and running
  • Git installed
  • Basic terminal knowledge

docs.title: Step 1: Project Initialization
docs.text:
# Create project directory
mkdir comp423-rust
cd comp423-rust

# Initialize Git repository
git init

docs.title: Step 2: Dev Container Configuration
docs.text:
1. Create .devcontainer/devcontainer.json: 
    {
    "name": "COMP423 Rust Environment",
    "image": "mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/rust:latest",
    "customizations": {
        "vscode": {
            "extensions": ["rust-lang.rust-analyzer"]
        }
    }
}

Key configuration elements: - Uses Microsoft's official Rust development container - Installs rust-analyzer for IDE features - Includes latest stable Rust toolchain

docs.title: Step 3: Create Rust Project
docs.text:
# Create binary project without automatic Git init
cargo new hello-comp423 --bin --vcs none

# Add files to Git
git add .
git commit -m "Initial project setup"

docs.title: Step 5: Build and Run
docs.text:
# Navigate to project root
cd /workspaces/RustSetup/comp423-rust/hello-comp423

# Build project (creates target/debug/hello-comp423)
cargo build

# Run directly from build output
./target/debug/hello-comp423

# Or build and run in one step
cargo run

Expected output: 

Hello COMP423!

docs.title: Workflow Explanation
docs.text:
# Full development workflow
cargo new <project-name> --bin --vcs none  # Project creation
cargo build                               # Compilation
cargo run                                 # Executions
cargo check                               # Quick compile check

docs.title: Verification Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Dev Container starts successfully
  • [ ] rustc --version shows recent version
  • [ ] cargo run outputs "Hello COMP423!"
  • [ ] Project committed to Git repository ```
